Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: An Investigation of the Commercial Potential of Cyber-physical Security for Advanced Manufacturing Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will provide the manufacturing industry with an approach to identify and detect cyber-physical attacks within their production environments in real-time. Currently, the manufacturing industry is operating production systems vulnerable to malicious attacks, which may cause produced parts to not meet intended design requirements. Such a deviation from design intent could result in damaged products, loss of customer trust, and potentially injure employees and/or customers. The adoption of the proposed approach will secure manufacturers from cyber-physical attacks and create a strong supply chain. This will allow manufacturers to continue to produce sensitive parts both for the general public and the defense industry, increasing the difficulty of a malicious attack to affect part production. Through successful completion of this program, the I-Corps team will further develop awareness in this area through mentoring graduate students and discussing cyber-physical security with manufacturers across the United States.

This I-Corps project employs both traditional decision analysis and data analysis techniques to identify and detect malicious events within manufacturing systems. This is done through a two-phase approach. First, a cyber-physical vulnerability assessment is completed which highlights areas within the production environment susceptible to malicious attack. Employing decision trees and process mapping, the vulnerability assessment is used to provide a high level overview of the cyber-physical resiliency of a manufacturing facility. Second, the proposed detection approach consists of an air-gapped sensor suite which can be placed on any piece of critical equipment to detect malicious events in real-time. The proposed approach analyzes side-channel measurements independent of the machine such as power consumption, vibration, and sound to identify anomalies within the process. Through performing the vulnerability assessment and implementing the proposed sensor suite, the entire production facility can be secured from malicious cyber-physical attacks intended to reduce part quality and/or sabotage produced parts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the I-Corps program, the team conducted 102 total interviews. Of these interviews, 78 were in person. During the initial kick-off meeting, the team attempted to visit over 15 facilities in the Bay area, but continually had problems with finding organizations willing to discuss security in their manufacturing enterprise. To address this issue, the project team decided to change the messaging away from security during the initial conversations and instead focus on Smart Manufacturing and the rise of Industry 4.0. This tactic proved to be successful and the team was able to pivot to security of manufacturing infrastructure during the customer interview. Additionally, we were able to meet with several industry practitioners from the IT side of the manufacturing community at the RSA conference, which was taking place in San Francisco during the kick-off meeting. It was entirely by chance that the kick-off meeting coincided with the RSA Conference, but proved to be a valuable resource in honing our message early in the process.

As we pivoted to customer interviews with those organizations interested in Smart Manufacturing, we continued to refine the type of organizations that aligned with our market segment. To this end, we began focusing on tier 2 defense manufacturers. This market segment is particularly vulnerable to potential malicious attacks against their infrastructure. The lower-tier defense manufacturers were more open to discussions about security and provided several opportunities for the I-Corps team to pursue.

These new revelations led the team to pursue multiple interview opportunities across the country. In addition to in-person interviews in the Bay Area, the Entrepreneurial Lead traveled to conferences in southeast Virginia, Boston, and several locations in Illinois. Together, these interviews provided a broad picture of the manufacturing community and their perspectives on security.

During the process, we determined that software and physical infrastructure investments in security were not the central area of interest for the manufacturing industry. Instead, they are more concerned about awareness and training of the workforce. Accordingly, the project team pivoted towards exploring the commercial viability of an ISO or Lean Six-Sigma style certification process for security in manufacturing. This pivot was a substantial deviation from the initial project ideas but provided a commercially viable alternative path.
